Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I sat at my desk, fingers poised over the keyboard, the code sample from my mentor half-finished on the screen. The assignment was due in three days, and I knew how much my mentor valued diligence and follow-through. I wanted to prove myself, to show I could be trusted with responsibility. Suddenly, the shrill wail of the building alarm cut through my concentration. My phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning—water was already creeping up the street outside. I glanced out the window and saw neighbors gathering, some struggling to move their cars or help the elderly evacuate. As a citizen, I felt the pull to join them, to do my part in keeping everyone safe, just as I’d always believed was right. But the unfinished code glared at me, a reminder of my promise to my mentor. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, torn between the urgent needs of my community and the commitment I’d made to my mentor.
